title: Recovering Plasmid DNA from Bacterial Culture
title_html: Recovering Plasmid DNA from Bacterial Culture

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description:
Grow an
overnight culture of bacteria.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
Refer to appropriate DNA prep protocol for volume of bacteria to grow (low copy plasmids require larger cultures).

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Centrifuge the culture to pellet the bacteria before proceeding with DNA preparation.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
If your entire overnight culture cannot fit into a single centrifuge tube, aliquot it into several tubes/bottles.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Remove the supernatant and resuspend the bacteria in buffer.

source.body: Note, this step gets all of the bacteria back into suspension, but within a smaller volume of buffer that is compatible with the next solution.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Add a denaturing solution to the resuspended bacteria.

source.body: Note, this step causes the bacteria to lyse, releasing their contents, including plasmid DNA, into solution.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Add a renaturing solution to the denatured bacteria.

source.body: Note, this step brings the pH back down causing the proteins and genomic DNA to precipitate, while leaving the smaller plasmids free in solution.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Pellet the proteins and genomic DNA by centrifugation, and remove the plasmid-containing supernatant.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Add either ethanol or isopropanol to precipitate the plasmid DNA.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Either spin to pellet the DNA or apply the solution to a column that will bind the now precipitated DNA.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description: Wash the pellet or column with 70% ethanol to remove excess salt.

source.title: Generalized DNA Purification

source.description:
Resuspend the DNA pellet, or elute the DNA off of the column using water or a neutral buffer such as TE. You will now have plasmid DNA that has been purified away from the bacterial proteins and genomic DNA. Depending on the method used, the DNA concentration and purity will vary. For more information on determining DNA concentration and purity click
here
.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Solution I - Resuspension Buffer
25 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8)
50 mM glucose
10 mM EDTA

source.body: Store Solution I at .

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Solution II - Denaturing Solution
0.2 N NaOH
1.0% SDS

source.body: Store Solution II at .

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Solution III - Renaturing Solution (Potassium Acetate)
5M Potassium acetate
glacial acetic acid
of dH2O

source.body: Store Solution III at .

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Grow
overnight cultures from single colonies of bacteria containing your plasmid of interest.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Add
of the stock culture to a
microfuge tube.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Centrifuge in microfuge tube at
for
.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: Pour off the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the bacterial pellet.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Resuspend the pellet in
of cold Solution I.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Vortex the solution for
or until all bacteria are fully resuspended.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Add
of Solution II and invert the tube carefully 5 times to mix the contents. The contents will become clear and thicker as the proteins and DNA are denatured.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
Do not vortex at this stage or the genomic DNA will become sheared and will therefore contaminate your purified plasmid DNA.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Incubate solution on ice for
.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Add
of cold Solution III to each tube.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: Mix by inverting several times. A white precipitate will be formed which contains the bacterial proteins and genomic DNA.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Incubate tube on ice for
.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Centrifuge the tube for
at
.

source.body:
Notes:
  • Pellet contains proteins, cell fragments, salt and other extra particles from solutions.
  • Supernatant contains the plasmid DNA separated from bacterial chromosomes.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: Collect the supernatant into a new tube by pipetting or carefully pouring.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
(Optional) Add
of 2 mg/ml RNase A to the supernatant in the new tube and incubate at
for
.

source.body: Note, Ribonuclease A (RNase A) is a pancreatic ribonuclease that digests single-stranded RNA.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: (Optional) Perform phenol-chloroform extraction - see protocol below.

source.body: Note, phenol-chloroform extraction removes remaining contaminant proteins and RNase A from the DNA sample. When phenol is mixed with the aqueous solution containing DNA, proteins will move into the phenol phase and will be separated from the aqueous DNA.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Add either
of cold 100% ethanol or
room temperature isopropanol to the solution to precipitate the plasmid DNA; see detailed protocol section below.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
If precipiating with ethanol, it is often thought that an incubation of to overnight at or will improve precipitation.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: Pour out the supernatant.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description: (Optional) Wash the pellet with 70% ethanol.

source.body: Note, this step removes excess salt from the pellet which can cause problems with some common reactions.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Air dry the pellet (can be done by inverting the tube at an angle over kimwipe) for
-
.

source.title: Protocol: Kit-free Alkaline Lysis Plasmid Miniprep

source.description:
Resuspend pellet with
-
of TE.

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description: Add an equal volume of TE-saturated phenol-chloroform to the aqueous DNA sample.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
Water-saturated phenol-chloroform can be used if TE-saturated is not available.

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description:
Vortex microfuge tube for
-
.

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description:
Centrifuge the tube for
at
on the highest speed setting.

source.body:
Note, you should see clearly separated layers:
Top Phase - Aqueous DNA phase
Middle phase - A white layer may appear, consisting of precipitated protein particles
Bottom phase - Organic phase (protein)

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description: Pipet the aqueous DNA layer and place it in a new microfuge tube.

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description: Add equal volume of chloroform to the recovered aqueous DNA layer.

source.title: Protocol: Phenol-Chloroform Extraction of DNA Samples

source.description: Repeat steps 2-4.

source.body: Phenol-chloroform is a hazardous waste - DO NOT pour down sink.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: To your DNA solution, add 2-2.5 volumes 95% or 100% ethanol and 1/10 volume of 3 M Na-acetate (pH 4.8).

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: Invert the microfuge tube to mix.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
(Optional) Place the tube either at
overnight OR
for
OR on dry ice for
.

source.body: Note, this freezing may help the DNA to precipitate.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
Centrifuge solution at high speed (at least
) for
-
at
.

source.body:
Notes:
  • Pellet contains the precipitated DNA.
  • Supernatant contains residues, salts, and water.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: Pour out the supernatant in the sink.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: Open and invert the tubes on a paper towel to drain them out.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
Wash pellet by adding
cold 70% ethanol.

source.body: Note, this helps to remove excess salt from the DNA pellet.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
Centrifuge solution at high speed (at least
) for
at
.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: Pour out the supernatant in the sink.

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
Be careful, the pellet is harder to see and less well attached to the tube after the 70% ethanol wash. You can also pipet the supernatant out of the tube if you are worried about losing the pellet.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
Dry with vacuum or by inverting over paper towel for
-
.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description: Resuspend dry DNA with TE (10 mM Tris-HCl pH 8, 0.1 mM EDTA).

source.body:
*Pro-Tip*
DNA resuspension can take time, it is a good idea to let it sit for several hours to overnight at room temperature before quantifying and using.

source.title: Protocol: Ethanol Precipitation

source.description:
Store DNA at
.

description: This protocol is for recovering plasmid DNA from Bacterial Culture. To see the full abstract and other resources, visit https://www.addgene.org/protocols/purify-plasmid-dna/.
